note.p: Ludwig XV 7, J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles. Paris, c. 1405
Parchment of good quality, with no significant flaws; a minor repair on 9r.
iv+136+ii. Catchwords lower right of versos throughout; no quire marks or signatures. Modern foliation in pencil, lower right, is accurate.

Ruled in red ink, no prickings survive. Ruled with eight vertical and two horizontal lines. Each column is delineated by a vertical through line on either side; two additional lines extend to the top of text block and separate the first letter of each line from the rest of the line. One horizontal through line at the top and bottom of text block. Two columns of 44 lines each. Text block varies in height from 255-260 mm, and is 169 mm in width; each column approximately 75mm wide. Ruled for two columns of 44 lines each
One main scribe using brown ink and textualis formata script throughout. Colophon in another hand in cursiva formata with initials touched in yellow.

Rubricated lines accompany miniatures, identify changes in speakers, and mark textual divisions. Opening initial on fol. 1 six lines in height; numerous initials throughout vary in size from one to three lines in height. Initials alternate blue and gold on red background and red and gold on blue background, all with white penwork. Opening folio contains three-sided frame containing alternating red and blue flower designs. Vine leaf tendrils extend from this frame and surround text in border of opening folio. Similar vines protrude from three-line initials at the beginnings of paragraphs.
The following expert opinion on the miniatures is included in the Getty catalog record:

p.hi: Eberhard König says that one of the artists in Ms. Ludwig XV 7 is very close to the Master of Marguerite d’Orleans. François Avril grouped this manuscript with Paris, Bibliotèque nationale, fr. 100-101; fr. 290; and lat. 7789. He suggested that this group of manuscripts should be added to the Bedford Trend group established by Meiss.

note.p: 18th-century French binding, 384 x 273 mm, attributed to Luc-Antoine Boyet, Derome le pere, or Antoine Michel Padeloupe. Bound in red morocco binding with six raised bands. Three gold-tooled fillets frame outside edges of front and back covers and also run along edges of boards. Gold tooling on spine, including title “ROMAN DE LA ROSE,” floral designs, and letter B in circle. Gilt edges. Marbled pastedowns. Both in front and back there is one paper flyleaf between marbled endpaper and parchment. Light blue silk bookmark.

Bookplates of Albert de Naurois and Irene & Peter Ludwig on front pastedown. de Naurois’s bookplate features the inscription “TANTUM PRODEST QUANTUM PROSUNT”. That of the Ludwigs features their names, “AACHEN”, and a cartoonish drawing of a face; below that a smaller similar plate with a different cartoon face and, written in pencil, “XV 7”.
Provenance provided by Getty catalog record:

p.hi: Jean du Rueil; Louis-Jean Gaignat [de Bure, Paris, April 1769, no. 1764]; Charles-Adrian Picard, Paris [Mérigot, Paris Januray 31, 1780, no. 524]; Philippe l'Ainé, Marseilles [Tilliard, Paris, February 6, 1792, no. 583]; Claude-Joseph Clos [Tilliard, Paris, November 9, 1812, no. 174]; William Beckford; Alexander, Tenth Duke of Hamilton; Royal Museum, Berlin [Sotheby's, London, May 23, 1889, lot 10]; Albert de Naurois (d. 1906); purchased by Eduard Rahir (1864-1924) in 1906; by purchase to Adolphe Bordes in 1906; by inheritance to his widow; by purchase to Jacques Guerin in 1948 [his sale, Sotheby's, London, July 13, 1977, lot 48]; Peter and Irene Ludwig, Aachen.
No 769 P & I vente Gaignat 1769 Vo = 1764

note.p: Title, written and underlined in black ink: Roman de La Rose
Below that, an excerpt from the Philip l'Ainé catalog has been glued. Below that has been glued a piece of paper with the following inscription:

p.hi:
Ce poeme est une imitation de lart daimer dovide
Il a ete Commencé par guillaume de Lorris poete et juris consulte Francois qui vivoit du tems de st. Louis et Mourut en 1260 ou 1262 vne dame dont Il etoit devenu – amoureux en est le sujet Lorris ni laiant pas achevé Jean Clopinel dit de Meung le Continua quarante ans apres la Mort de Lorris Clement Marot la Fait imprimer en 1527 avec tant de changemens et de Corrections que le texte en a ete alteré Il a eté reimprimé en 1529 en Caracteres romains et en 1537 pour la 3e fois en Caracters Gothiques
Enfin labbé Lenglet Dufresnoy en a Fait vne nouvelle traduction quil a Fait imprimer en 1735.

Qui ne va il ne voit
qui ne voit il ne scet
qui ne scet il ne cougnoit
qui ne cougnoit il ne vault
qui ne vault il na Riens
qui na riens il est p[er]du
cest bien dit

Ayme qui voura
le myeux qui poura
se nest que soucy
car amours sans cy
Jamais ne sera

Qui trop aymera
touiours y sera
sugebt[?] a mercy
aime qui voura

Ou danger nuira
Toujours y paura
sella ou secy
la chose est ansy
amours ainsy va
